issues.text: The question to be decided in this case is whether in view of the correspondence which has been reproduced, it could be held that there was a concluded contract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff on the 14th August, as stated by him in the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: The question to be decided in this case is whether in view of the companyrespondence which has been reproduced, it companyld be held that there was a companycluded companytract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff on the 14th August, as s

issues.text: The real question is whether the first defendant had made a counter-offer in his cable of the 5th August or he was merely inviting offers.

anchor.surface_text: The real question is whether the first defendant had made a companynter-offer in his cable of the 5th August or he was merely inviting offers. The plaintiff in his letter of the 14th August addressed to Youngman, stated that he companyfirmed his oral offer

arguments.claim: There was a concluded contract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff on the 14th August

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner of Coorg who tried the suit held that there was a concluded contract, but, instead of giving to the plaintiff a decree for specific performance, awarded a sum of Rs. 3,000 as compensation to him.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: owing terms- Hold offer for Morvern Bungalow rupees eleven thousand cash subject immediately acceptance and occupation. Strongly recommend acceptance.

arguments.court_reasoning: Difficult to hold on entire facts; supported by Harvey v Facey; subsequent conduct shows invitation to offer

arguments.claim: The cable 'Wont accept less than rupees ten thousand' was a counter-offer made by the first defendant through Youngman to the plaintiff, and the contract was complete upon acceptance

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that the cable sent by the first defendant on the 5th August, and received by Youngman on the 8th, to the effect that he would not accept less than Rs. 10,000, was a counter-offer made by him through Youngman to the plaintiff, and the contract was complete as soon as he accepted it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Difficult to hold; Harvey v Facey similar; parties' subsequent conduct treated as invitation to offer, not counter-offer

anchor.surface_text: We however find it difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any concluded contract on the 14th August, 1944, and we are supported in this view by the well-known case of Harvey v. Facey 1

arguments.claim: First defendant's cable was mere statement of price like in Harvey v Facey, not unconditional offer or counter-offer; everything else left open

anchor.surface_text: In that case... Their Lordships cannot treat the telegram from L.M. Facey as binding him in any respect, except to the extent it does by its terms, viz., the lowest price. Everything else is left open... mere statement of the lowest price... contains no implied contract to sell

arguments.claim: Subsequent correspondence shows parties treated the cable as invitation to offers, not counter-offer

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion at which we have arrived is strengthened by certain facts which emerge from the correspondence between the parties. The real question is whether the first defendant had made a counter-offer... Neither party thus treated the first defendants cable as containing a counter-offer. On the other hand, they proceeded on the footing that the plaintiff had made an offer of Rs. 10,000 which was subject to acceptance by the first defendant.

arguments.claim: Youngman came under influence of rival bidder or White, and deliberately framed cable on 26th August to prejudice the plaintiff

holdings.text: We however find it difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any concluded contract on the 14th August, 1944

anchor.surface_text: We however find it difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any concluded contract on the 14th August, 1944, and we are supported in this view by the well-known case of Harvey v. Facey 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entire facts of case make it difficult to hold concluded contract; supported by Harvey v. Facey precedent where price statement not offer

holdings.text: Their Lordships cannot treat the telegram from L.M. Facey as binding him in any respect, except to the extent it does by its terms, viz., the lowest price. Everything else is left open

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Harvey v. Facey to facts: defendant's cable analogous to Facey's telegram, mere price info not binding offer or counter-offer

holdings.text: Neither party thus treated the first defendants cable as containing a counter-offer. On the other hand, they proceeded on the footing that the plaintiff had made an offer of Rs. 10,000 which was subject to acceptance by the first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion at which we have arrived is strengthened by certain facts which emerge from the correspondence between the parties. holdings.text: There is however nothing in the evidence to support such an extreme conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: There is however nothing in the evidence to support such an extreme conclusion. On the other hand, Youngman has frankly stated in his evidence that he felt it improper to entertain Subbayyas higher offer and did not communicate it to the first defendant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence supports claim of deliberate prejudice by Youngman; his testimony credible and consistent with cables

anchor.surface_text: Harvey v. Facey 1 , in which the facts were somewhat similar to those of the present case. In that case, the appellants had telegraphed to the respondents Will you sell us B.H.P.? Telegraph lowest cash price , and the respondents had telegraphed in reply, Lowest price for B.H.P. pound 900, and then the appellants telegraphed,

precedents.cited_proposition: A mere statement of lowest price in response to inquiry is not an unconditional offer to sell but only provides the price information, leaving the offer to sell open for acceptance
precedents.cited_holding: The telegram from L.M. Facey stating his lowest price as an unconditional offer to sell to them at the price named. Their Lordships cannot treat the telegram from L.M. Facey as binding him in any respect, except to the extent it does by its terms, viz., the lowest price. Everything else is left open
